column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=4. Quantitative Consequence Assessment of Slope Failures
#Text=Radiating Scan Method
#Text=As the sliding volumes will be used later to explain the differences of the two approaches , a procedure called the radiating scan method is proposed and briefly introduced here .
#Text=To quantify the failure volume , an estimation of slip area ( A ) has to be made for the problem .
#Text=This is done by locating the rupture surface first , then smoothing this surface and at last , finding the arc length ( ) and A by integration .

#Text=The technique used in has been adopted to define the rupture surface based on the shear strain invariant , ( 3 ) in which , and are the normal strains in the x and y directions and shear strain , respectively .
#Text=First , the maximum shear strain invariant was found along the line just below the toe and the line just below the slope face .
#Text=Next , an imaginary point in space , above the centre of the slope face , was chosen .

#Text=Then , a series of lines radiating out from this point ( across the slope mesh , clockwise ) was considered ( the first radiating line is the line connecting the point located in the first step and the imaginary point ) .
#Text=The maximum value of shear strain invariant along each line ( i.e. , clockwise ) was detected and , by connecting the locus of maxima from all the lines , the rupture surface was defined .
#Text=This is shown in
#Text=Figure 5
#Text=schematically .
#Text=Note that the shear strain invariant within an element is interpolated using the shape functions .
#Text=However , no precise information about the length of the rupture surface is available by adopting the above-mentioned Radiation Scan method only .

#Text=A procedure is implemented to smooth the curve by polynomial curve fitting ; that is , by finding the coefficients of a polynomial of degree n that fits the data , to , in a least squares sense , ( ) are the coordinate pair defining the rupture surface ) .
#Text=By doing so , the rippled curve shown in
#Text=Figure 6
#Text=is smoothed to the curve shown in red .
#Text=Next , the arc length is found by numerically integrating between 0.5 and 10 : ( 4 )
#Text=Figure 6
#Text=shows that the slip area is found by computing the integral of p with respect to x , using repeated trapezium integration and then subtracting the area of the triangle above the slope face .
#Text=For the present slope geometry and failure mechanism , the integrated length of the rupture surface is m and the slip area is m2 .
